Comment: Depends on how much medical care they need.  I’m all for trans rights, but there is an expectation of readiness for deployment.  If someone is undergoing operations that make them unable to deploy or are requiring special medications during deployments then it causes issues.  I’ve seen people removed because they found out they were diabetic at age 19, pregnancies cause issues and remove people from rotations. If you go into the military and then start requiring additional/special medical attention then you shouldn’t be in, that’s just the reality of things.

Comment: I know someone who was rejected during basic for having poorly controlled asthma. The bar is pretty low for medical conditions that can disqualify — needing special medication that only a small minority of service members require is undeniably a logistical burden.   But also, fuck Trump, this wasn’t a real issue causing real day-to-day problems; it’s just red meat for the Fox News crowd.
Author: Begging_Murphy

Comment: The original order had some bs about truthfulness and good discipline and that preferred pronouns are not compatible with a strong military. If Trump wanted to exclude those requiring ongoing medical care or with legitimate concerns about mental health or its treatment, it would have legitimacy as an argument. A person who has a male body and has had no medical treatment and has no medical needs and simply says they’d like to be called she/her or grow out their hair is included in this order. That shows it’s based on intolerance and exclusion rather than fitness or burdening the military.
